This research aims to develop and characterize innovative metal-based catalysts made of micro-mesoporous silica enriched with iron and molybdenum. The goal is to optimize the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, promoting the production of the bioadditive solketal at ambient temperatures. X-ray diffraction analyses demonstrated the formation of orthorhombic molybdenum trioxide, showcasing excellent oxide dispersion on the support and remarkably low crystallinity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses have convincingly shown the presence of molybdenum (VI) and iron (III), signifying the successful formation of active species. By carefully optimizing conditions – specifically a reaction duration of 90 min, a temperature maintained at 25 °C, a catalyst loading of 5 % by weight (catalyst/glycerol), and a molar ratio of 1:4 (glycerol/acetone) – a conversion of 82 % and selectivity of 97 % for solketal were achieved. This result highlights the high efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed catalytic process. Reuse tests of the most efficient catalyst indicate satisfactory activity up to the third cycle, with a reduction in catalytic efficiency of 12 %, demonstrating high efficiency. These results demonstrate the great potential of these catalysts in sustainable industrial chemical processes, aligning with the innovative principles of green chemistry. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Glycerol Solketal production Fe-Mo-silica composite Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The Industrial Revolution modernized the industrial sector, leading to more resources, lower prices, and a better quality of life for people [1]. However, this change also created a high energy demand, mainly from non-renewable sources like oil. These resources are limited, and burning fossil fuels releases harmful gases, contributing to environmental problems like global warming, acid rain, and the greenhouse effect. In this situation, biofuels offer a cleaner and renewable alternative. Biofuels, which can be used alongside or instead of oil-based fuels, represent a significant technological improvement. They help lower greenhouse gas emissions significantly [2]. Biodiesel is an important biofuel that is increasingly used to replace fossil fuels in diesel blends. It is non-toxic, devoid of sulfur, and derived from renewable sources, rendering it environmentally friendly [3]. Biodiesel is predominantly produced through the transesterification of vegetable oils, which simultaneously yields glycerol as a principal byproduct, constituting approximately 10 % of the total mass [1]. As biodiesel production escalates, so does the quantity of surplus glycerol. In 2023, Brazil generated 680,000 tons of glycerol, while total exports amounted to 448,000 tons [4]. Nevertheless, a substantial portion of this glycerol remains unutilized due to the high costs associated with large-scale purification. This circumstance impacts the economic viability of biodiesel production, contingent upon the effective management of glycerol. Consequently, scientists are increasingly exploring methods to convert this surplus glycerol into more valuable products [4–6]. Glycerol acetalization represents one of the most efficacious methods to augment the value of this byproduct. This process produces two structural isomers: (2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxolan-4-yl) methanol (solketal) and 2,2-dimethyl-1,3-dioxane-5-ol (R6M), with water generated as a byproduct. Solketal exhibits greater thermodynamic stability than R6M, attributable to steric repulsions arising from the methyl group positioned axially [5] (Fig. 1 ). Solketal, the product resulting from this reaction, is a promising fuel additive due to its ability to increase octane ratings and provide greater oxidative stability. Incorporating solketal into fuels helps reduce particle emissions and minimize the formation of undesirable deposits in tank bottoms, thus improving fuel efficiency [7,8]. Additionally, it enhances fuel performance in colder climates by reducing fuel viscosity. Currently, the conversion of glycerol to solketal is performed using significant amounts of homogeneous acid catalysts, such as hydrochloric acid (HCl) and sulfuric acid (H2SO4) [7]. However, this approach has several limitations and disadvantages, including non-recyclable chemicals and high costs in the separation and purification processes. On the other hand, heterogeneous catalysts offer significant advantages, such as the ability to be easily separated and recovered, reducing the consumption of natural resources, and reducing the amount of waste generated. The conversion of glycerol to solketal in a heterogeneous catalytic medium occurs preferentially in the presence of Brønsted or Lewis acid sites located on the surface of solid catalysts. Both types of sites are catalytically active, but differ in their mechanisms of action, particularly in the activation of the acetone carbonyl group: Brønsted acid sites promote protonation, while Lewis acid sites activate the carbonyl through electronic coordination, thereby facilitating the subsequent nucleophilic attack [9]. Additionally, for this specific reaction, Brønsted acid sites tend to play a more decisive role, especially in the initial activation step, whereas Lewis acid sites contribute synergistically [10,11]. Heterogeneous catalysts based on noble metals stand out for their high efficiency in various chemical reactions, primarily due to their acidic properties, which enhance catalytic activity and selectivity for alcohol conversion reactions, such as glycerol conversion [12–14]. To reduce the costs associated with noble metal-based catalysts and improve catalytic efficiency, catalysts based on transition metals such as Fe, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Mo have emerged as promising alternatives when applied to the active centers of catalysts [14]. The incorporation of dispersed metal species into inert matrices, such as mesoporous silica, represents an effective strategy for the development of heterogeneous catalysts. Silica-based dispersions exhibit high surface area, chemical stability, and excellent ability to disperse metal species on their surface [15]. Among the main advantages of this approach is the ability to generate acid sites with enhanced accessibility, due to the porous structure of the material—an essential characteristic for efficient performance in various catalytic reactions [16]. Metal species such as molybdenum, present as Mo⁶⁺ in dispersed MoO₃ on silica, can act as unsaturated metal centers capable of accepting electron pairs from adsorbed molecules, thus functioning as Lewis acid sites. Additionally, molybdenum can interact with surface silanol groups (Si–OH) of silica, leading to the formation of molybdenum-bound hydroxyl groups (Mo–OH), which can donate protons and thereby behave as Brønsted acid sites [17]. From a broader perspective, the use of bimetallic catalysts, which incorporate combinations of more than one metal, achieves properties not feasible with single-metal systems. The enhanced catalytic efficiency of these catalysts results from synergistic effects between the constituent metals [12,18]. These catalysts are particularly promising due to the extensive range of possible compositional modifications. In particular, iron does not merely coexist with molybdenum but actively modifies its electronic and structural environment, which enhances acid site accessibility, increases the number of active centers, and ultimately improves catalytic performance [18,19]. Moreover, the introduction of a second metal can enhance the acidity of the catalyst, thereby favoring the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules on the catalytic surface [20]. The enhanced catalytic performance of Fe–Mo bimetallic catalysts is attributed to a synergistic interaction that modulates both electronic and structural properties of the active sites. As demonstrated by Arias-Madrid et al. (2020) [21], the combination of Fe₂O₃ and MoO₃ dispersed on SiO₂ leads to improved metal dispersion, increased surface acidity, and more accessible catalytic sites—factors that collectively enhance the overall catalytic activity In this context, the present study reports the development of composite catalysts composed of micro-mesoporous silica and molybdenum and iron oxides, synthesized via the co-condensation technique, to generate active acid sites on the material's surface. Additionally, the effect of incorporating different amounts of iron on the catalytic and structural properties of these materials was investigated. These catalysts were specifically designed for application in the acetalization reaction of glycerol with acetone, aiming to produce the bioadditive solketal under ambient temperature conditions. The results consistently demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed catalysts, highlighting their potential to promote a more efficient and environmentally sustainable catalytic process. Moreover, they emphasize the remarkable potential of these catalysts to advance sustainable chemical processes. By enabling solketal production at lower temperatures, this catalyst system showcases significant promise in minimizing energy consumption and enhancing the overall environmental footprint of bioadditive manufacturing. The development of these tailored catalysts embodies a powerful movement toward the wider adoption of green chemistry principles in industrial practices. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of the C-SiMo catalyst The catalyst C-SiMo was synthesized via co-condensation, employing ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate as the molybdenum precursor, the surfactant Cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB - Sigma-Adrich), as a structure-directing template, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS - Aldrich) as the silica source, NaOH as the mineralizing agent, and deionized water as the solvent, adapting the methodologies described by [13,14]. Initially, 1.40 g of CTAB was dissolved in 30.0 g of Milli-Q water and 10.0 mL of a 1.0 mol L⁻¹ NaOH (Synth), solution under stirring at 25 °C. After 1 h of stirring, 5.00 g of TEOS was added slowly (dropwise), maintaining the mixture at 40 °C and pH 11 for 2 h. Subsequently, the pH was adjusted to 3.0 with HCl 2.0 mol L⁻¹, and 10 mL of ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24 ·4H2O – Scientific Exodus) 0.036 mol L⁻¹ solution was added dropwise using a burette [14]. The synthesis was carried out to achieve a molar ratio of 0.10 between molybdenum (Mo) and silicon (Si), corresponding to 10 mol % of Mo. The mixture was maintained under constant stirring for 24 h at 40 °C and pH 3.0. The solid obtained was washed with deionized water until pH of 7.0 was reached. After it was dried and heated at 550 °C in an oven, the isothermal step was 5 h, and the heating rate was 1 °C/min. 2.2 Preparation of the C-SiMoFex catalyst The silica-supported iron and molybdenum catalysts were synthesized using the co-condensation method, following the same procedure established for synthesizing the C-SiMo catalyst. The synthesis followed the established procedure used for C-SiMo. Specifically, 1.40 g of CTAB was dissolved in 40.0 g of deionized water containing NaOH, along with appropriate amounts of ammoniacal iron sulfate Fe(NH4)2(SO4)2·6H2O – (Synth); 0.0645 g, 0.193 g, and 0.268 g) to obtain a mixed oxide of SiO2/Fe2O3/MoO3 with iron concentrations of 0.5 % C-SiMoFe1(0.5), 1.5 % (C-SiMoFe2 (1.5), and 2 % (C-SiMoFe3(2.0). The mixture was maintained under stirring at 40 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, 5.0 g of TEOS (silica source) was added dropwise with the aid of a burette. The mixture was maintained under stirring for 2 h at 40 °C and pH 11. After this period, the pH of the solution was adjusted to 3.0 using a 2.0 mol l -1 HCl solution, and 10 mL of the ammonium molybdate solution were added dropwise. The mixture was maintained under constant stirring for 24 h at 40 °C and pH 3.0. The solids were washed until reaching pH 7.0, dried in a furnace, and subjected to thermal treatment at 550 °C for 5 h, with a heating rate of 1 °C/min. 2.3 Characterization techniques Powder X-ray diffraction patterns for structure and phase identification were conducted using a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer equipped with a copper tube, Soller slit, and ultra-fast linear detector LynxEye, operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. The radiation source employed was CuKα, with a wavelength of 1.5406 nm. Data were collected through a counting time of 1.0 s per point, utilizing a step size of 0.02°s-1 and a diffraction angle (2θ) ranging from 2 to 70° The textural properties were measured in a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface area and porosity analyzer at a pressure range of 10–6 < P/Po < 0.99. The sample was degassed for 3 h at 250 °C and 4.0 μm Hg in a quartz tube before the measurement. The BET surface area was assessed by the multipoint method of nitrogen adsorption in the 0.05<P/Po<0.2 range, and the surface area of micropores was calculated using the Dubinin–Astakhov (DA) equation. The Dubinin–Astakhov exponent (n) indicates the degree of heterogeneity of a micropore system [22], so that the narrower the micropore size range, the more homogeneous the distribution and, for adsorbents, n < 2 is assigned to heterogeneous micropore distributions [23]. The value of the DA exponent was n ∼ 1, indicating that these samples present a heterogeneous micropore network. Pore size distributions were calculated using the non-local density functional theory (NLDFT), assuming slit-shaped pores. Simultaneous thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA) of the solids was conducted using a Shimadzu DTG 60H model equipment. The TG-DTA experiments were performed in an uncovered α-alumina crucible (70 µL), using a sample mass of approximately 4.0 mg, a heating rate of 20 °C min-1, a dry air atmosphere with a flow rate of 100 mL min-1, and a temperature range of 30 to 1000 °C. Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy and the characterization of acidic sites were carried out using a Nicolet iS10 spectrometer. The measurements employed the attenuated total reflectance (ATR) accessory with a diamond crystal, acquiring 32 scans at a resolution of 4 cm-1 in the 4000–550 cm-1 range. To characterize acidic sites, 10.0 mg of each sample was thermally treated in a tubular muffle furnace at 200 °C for 2 h under an N2 flow to eliminate adsorbed water. After cooling, 20.0 µL of liquid pyridine was added, and the samples were stored in a desiccator for 24 h. The samples were then treated at 150 °C for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed pyridine. After a second cooling period, the samples were transferred to Eppendorf tubes for FTIR analysis, following an adapted methodology from G.F. Leal and co-workers [24]. The elemental composition of the material was determined via inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) with a Thermo Scientific iCAP 7000 series spectrometer. The ICP-OES operational parameters included a radiofrequency power source set at 1150 W, an argon plasma flow rate, an argon nebulizer flow rate, and a defined sample flow rate. The most sensitive emission lines (wavelengths) used were 202.030 (467) for molybdenum and 259.940 nm (130) for iron. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha model spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα source (energy = 1486 eV). The individual atom energies were calibrated relative to carbon, and data acquisition was performed using the CasaXPS software. The morphology and elemental composition of the samples were also examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) coupled with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX). The SEM analysis was conducted using a Quanta 200 FEG FEI 14 (2006) microscope. Gold metallization was applied to the samples using a Shimadzu ICSO coater, in which a small amount of each sample was placed on an aluminum sample holder with carbon adhesive. The analyses were conducted at the UFMG Microscopy Center. 2.4 Acetalization of glycerol with acetone Evaluating the materials as catalysts for the solketal acetalization reaction followed the procedure described by Balotin and co-workers (2023) [25]. Typical reactions were carried out with 0.921 g of glycerol (0.0100 mol), 2.324 g of acetone (0.0400 mol), 0.0450 g of catalyst (≈5 % relative to glycerol), and 0.132 g of 1,4-dioxane (0.00150 mol) as an internal standard, over 300 min, at controlled temperatures of approximately 25 °C or 45 °C. After completion, the total reaction time under standard catalytic test conditions was 300 min. For catalyst reuse studies, the reaction time was reduced to 90 min, and the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The obtained products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) from Shimadzu, using a Shimadzu instrument equipped with an automatic injector (AOC-5000)), a polyethylene glycol capillary column (DB-Wax) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The experimental setup involved stirring the mixture at a consistent rate of 700 rpm (rpm), with a glycerol-to-acetone molar ratio of 1:4. A catalyst loading of 5 wt % was employed, and the reaction was maintained at a controlled room temperature of approximately 25 °C. For this investigation, 45 mg of catalyst was utilized. To monitor the progress of the reaction, aliquots were collected at specific time intervals ranging from 10 to 300 min. Catalyst mass evaluations were conducted over similar time intervals, ranging (starting at 10 or 20 min), corresponding to periods during which the liquid phase of the reaction medium remained homogeneous. This ensured negligible mass transfer limitations. The amount of glycerol converted ( %) was calculated as shown in Eq. (1). The selectivity (S) of the catalyst for solketal was calculated according to Eq. (2). (Eq. 2) S = n s o l n s o l + n 6 M R x 100 Where nsol and n6MR are the number of moles of solketal and 6MR produced at the end of the reaction, respectively. The low-angle diffractograms (Fig. 2 A) revealed that the materials synthesized in the presence of a surfactant did not exhibit the characteristic diffraction peaks typically associated with ordered mesoporous structures. The absence of these reflections suggests the formation of disordered mesoporous materials composed of mixed oxides of silica, molybdenum, and iron. In the wide-angle diffractograms (Fig. 2B), all samples displayed a broad peak centered around 2θ = 23°, indicative of an amorphous or poorly crystalline silica structure. For the C-SiMo, C-SiMoFe1, and C-SiMoFe2 catalysts, low-intensity peaks were observed at 2θ = 12.82° (020), 23.02° (110), 25.90° (040), and 27.50° (021), which were attributed to the orthorhombic phase of MoO₃, as referenced by the JCPDS 05–0508 standard (space group Pbnm) [27], and are indicative of highly dispersed crystalline domains. No diffraction peaks corresponding to iron oxide or other iron-containing phases were detected, suggesting that these species are present in either an amorphous state or as highly dispersed nanometric domains, thereby hindering their detection by XRD [28]. The percentage of metal incorporation was quantified through the ICP-OES technique. This amorphous structure on the catalysts suggests a disordered structure that may contribute to the formation of different types of active sites [29,30]. Amorphous materials, due to their disordered structure, can provide greater exposure of active sites. In addition, they exhibit a high density of unsaturated atomic sites and dangling bonds on their surfaces, which can serve as active centers, thus enhancing catalytic activity [31,32]. This property is beneficial for catalytic functions as it potentially increases the available surface area for phenomena such as adsorption and heterogeneous catalysis. Additionally, the straightforward and cost-efficient production processes for amorphous materials on an industrial scale make them highly advantageous for a range of applications in various sectors[30]. The N₂ adsorption isotherms and pore size distributions obtained by the NLDFT method for the synthesized catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 (a–b), while the derived textural properties are presented in Table 1 . All materials exhibited mixed type I(b) and IV(a) isotherms with an H4 hysteresis loop, according to the IUPAC classification [33], suggesting the combined presence of micropores and mesopores. This profile may indicate the existence of a complex porous network, which is often associated with the combination of narrow channels and interconnected larger cavities [34]. For the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst, it was observed that it presents the highest relative contribution of micropores, with a pore volume of 0.0237 cm³·g⁻¹ (11.4 %) in the 1.0–1.5 nm range and 0.0526 cm³·g⁻¹ (25.4 %) in the 1.5–2.0 nm range, totaling 36.8 % micropores. This highlights that, particularly in C-SiMoFe2, microporosity represents a structurally relevant fraction. This observation is consistent with the Dubinin–Astakhov exponent values (n ≈ 1), which indicate a moderately heterogeneous microporous network [35]. Regarding mesoporosity, all materials exhibited a predominant pore distribution in the 2–5 nm range, with C-SiMoFe2 showing a mesopore volume of 0.1308 cm³·g⁻¹ (63.2 %), suggesting that the incorporation of iron promoted not only an increase in surface area but also a reorganization of the porous structure [4]. On the other hand, taking C-SiMo as a reference material, it showed the lowest adsorptive capacity, with a micropore volume of 0.0264 cm³·g⁻¹ (25.6 %) and a mesopore volume of 0.0769 cm³·g⁻¹ (74.4 %), which can be attributed to its less developed structure. The C-SiMoFe1 sample also exhibited good textural performance, with a total pore volume of 0.2002 cm³·g⁻¹, although with a lower proportion of micropores (21.5 %) than C-SiMoFe2. These results suggest that the composition and proportion of incorporated metals directly influence the pore hierarchy of the catalysts [5]. Additionally, the ICP analysis (Table 1) confirms that the incorporation of Mo and Fe by the adopted method was efficient, emphasizing the C-SiMoFe3 sample, which showed the highest iron content (2.0 %). The combination of high microporosity, accessible mesopores, and controlled doping with molybdenum and iron oxides suggests that the developed catalysts may exhibit superior performance in catalytic reactions limited by internal diffusion of reactants [36]. The thermal properties of the materials were investigated using data from the TG-DTA curves, as shown in Fig. 4 (a–d). The TG curves reveal a mass loss region between 30 °C and 150 °C, which corresponds to a broad endothermic peak in the DTA curve. This peak can be attributed to dehydration resulting from the release of physisorbed water molecules, retained on the surface through weak van der Waals interactions. Above this temperature, a small, gradual, and very slow mass loss of approximately 3 % is observed between 150 °C and 400 °C. This loss is likely due to the decomposition of residual surfactant or the release of water molecules more strongly bound to the matrix surface via chemical bonds, typically covalent—a process known as chemisorption. This behavior is characteristic of the highly hygroscopic nature of the material [37]. The mass loss at higher temperatures, accompanied by exothermic peaks—occurring at approximately 737 °C for C-SiMo, 771 °C for C-SiMoFe1, 843 °C for C-SiMoFe2, and 828 °C for C-SiMoFe3—is more clearly visualized in the enlarged region of Fig.4 (a–d). As shown, discrete mass losses occur nearly simultaneously with the exothermic thermal events. Based on supporting evidence from the literature [38], it can be inferred that the amorphous catalysts, based on X-ray diffraction findings, undergo structural rearrangement that induces crystallization, followed by partial thermal decomposition likely involving the molybdenum oxide phase itself [39–41]. Moreover, the increasing crystallization temperatures — generally following the order C-SiMo< C-FeMo1< C-FeMo2 ∼ C-FeMo3 — suggest that higher concentrations of iron oxide influence the crystallization temperature of molybdenum oxide [42]. The FTIR/ATR analysis, Fig. 5 (a–d), shows that the samples exhibit similar characteristic bands across the samples, indicating the same structural organization among the materials. The transmittance bands observed at 794 cm⁻¹ and 1060 cm⁻¹ can be attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibrations of Si–O–Si groups, typical of silica-based materials [43,44]. This suggests that the primary structure of the catalysts predominantly involves silicate bonds. The doublet of peaks at 912 cm⁻¹ and 950 cm⁻¹ is due to stronger interactions between the metal species (Mo or Fe) and the SiO₂ matrix. These peaks are related to the formation of metal-oxygen bonds (Si–O–M), where "M" represents the metal incorporated into the catalyst structure. Thus, through these interactions, it is possible to infer that the metals are not only physically adsorbed on the silica but also appear to be chemically integrated, forming covalent bonds that result in the structural stability of the catalyst [45]. The analysis reveals notable variations in peak intensities and subtle shifts in wavenumber across the four catalysts: (a) C-SiMo, (b) C-SiMoFe1, (c) C-SiMoFe2, and (d) C-SiMoFe3. These discrepancies indicate different metal loadings and the corresponding unique environments surrounding the metal sites. Additionally, minor wavenumber shifts may suggest alterations in bond strength or coordination numbers. The FTIR/ATR analysis demonstrates that while these catalysts possess a common structural framework heavily influenced by silicate groups, the degree of metal incorporation significantly affects the chemical interactions within the silica matrix. These interactions play a crucial role in determining the catalytic performance of each material. To elucidate the surface composition and the nature of the metallic species (Fe and Mo) on the catalyst surfaces, we conducted X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the C-SiMo and C-SiMoFe2 catalysts, which serve as representative samples for the other materials studied. The comprehensive XPS spectra presented in Fig. 6 (a, b) for both catalysts indicate the presence of silicon, oxygen, and molybdenum. The Si2p signal observed at 104.4 eV is associated with SiO2, while the peak at 535.9 eV is attributable to oxygen. Notably, the doublet peaks in the 234 to 237 eV range indicate molybdenum, with no detectable signals from other metallic species on the surface. The high-resolution spectra, shown in Fig. 6(c, d), highlight the Mo 3d transitions in the C-SiMo and C-SiMoFe2 catalysts. The Mo 3d core level exhibits two components separated by spin-orbit coupling,3d5/2 and 3d3/2, with an energy separation of 3.2 eV [46]. In Fig. 6(c), the spectrum of the C-SiMo catalyst shows these components at 234.17 and 237.17 eV, while in Fig. 6(d), the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 components of the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst are observed at 234.40 and 237.58 eV, respectively. The binding energy value of 232.20 eV for the Mo 3d5/2 component is consistent with the presence of molybdenum in the VI oxidation state (MoO3) [47].For the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst, a definitive shift toward higher binding energies compared to pure MoO3 is evident. This is attributed to the significant interactions between the metal and the support [48]. Strong interactions between the metal and the support enhance charge transfer, increasing the binding energy. Handzlik and colleagues [32] noted that monomeric species can be formed when Mo atoms are supported on silica. Multiple molybdenum species indicate complex metal-support interactions; however, the expanded Mo 3d spectra could not be deconvoluted into additional doublets representing Mo(V) or Mo (IV) species. The full XPS spectrum for the Fe 2p region of the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst, shown in Fig. 6(e), reveals two distinct peaks corresponding to the spin-orbit components Fe 2p1/2 and Fe 2p3/2, respectively. According to the literature, these binding energies can be attributed to Fe(III) ions in α-Fe2O3 [49]. Therefore, the predominant oxidation states of the metallic species on the catalyst surface are Mo(VI) as MoO3 and Fe(III) as α-Fe2O3. These findings emphasize the distinct oxidation states of the metals in the catalyst matrix, which is important for understanding their contribution to the catalytic performance of glycerol-to-solketal conversion. SEM images of the C-SiMo and C-FeMo2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7 (a–f) as representative of other samples. For the C-SiMo catalyst, depicted in Fig. 7(a-c), the images reveal a sequence that may indicate the dispersion of molybdenum in the silica. Fig. 7, which corresponds to the molybdenum mapping highlighted in blue, shows a uniform distribution of this metal across the entire surface. Subsequently, Fig. 7b shows that the material has particles of various sizes. It can be observed in Fig. 7c that the surface of each particle presents sub-particles with a more elongated or ellipsoidal shape, and some are present in almost cylindrical aspects. This characteristic may indicate anisotropic growth during formation despite the surface presenting regularity. The X-ray diffraction data confirm that the material is not crystalline. The images depicting the metal oxide catalysts, particularly the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst showcased in Fig. 7(d–f), illustrate the spatial distribution of silicon, molybdenum, and iron elements within the catalyst structure. Utilizing the Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) technique, the ratio of molybdenum to iron constituents has been quantified at approximately 9.44 % for molybdenum and 1.15 % for iron. This finding emphasizes the compositional balance present in the catalyst. As illustrated in Fig. 7(d,e), the distribution of these elements across the catalyst particles is remarkably uniform, suggesting an even incorporation of the constituents throughout the material. In Fig. 7(f), a closer examination reveals a diverse array of particle sizes and shapes, indicating variability in the physical structure of the catalyst. Moreover, it can be inferred that the inclusion of iron has led to an enhancement in the surface roughness of the material, which, in turn, has increased its porosity compared to the original C-SiMo catalyst. This transformation is further corroborated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments, which demonstrate that the introduction of iron into the catalyst system, regardless of the specific quantity used, produces a consistently similar porosity throughout the material. This characteristic increase in porosity and surface texture is crucial for enhancing the catalyst's performance in various applications. EDS analysis confirms that the metals are distributed homogeneously throughout the SiO2, which can ensure consistent catalytic performance throughout the material. The characteristics of surface acid sites in metal oxide–SiO₂ catalysts were investigated using pyridine (Py) as a probing molecule. FTIR spectroscopy, a method widely acknowledged in the literature for its effectiveness, was utilized to achieve this. Pyridine interacts with acid sites on catalyst surfaces, forming species that exhibit distinct vibrational frequencies. This interaction provides valuable insights into both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites present on the catalysts [50]. The FTIR spectra of the catalysts C-SiMo-Py, C-SiMoFe1-Py, C-SiMoFe2, and C-SiMoFe3 exhibit no absorption bands in the region of 1400 cm⁻¹ to 1600 cm⁻¹, as illustrated in Fig.8 (a–d). However, upon exposure to pyridine, distinct absorption bands emerge in the FTIR spectra, as shown in Fig. 8(a–d). The prominent band at 1541 cm⁻¹ indicates a strong hydrogen bond formed via proton transfer, signaling the presence of Brønsted acid sites (B). In contrast, the band at 1446 cm⁻¹ results from the coordination of the electron pair from pyridine with metal centers, reflecting the existence of Lewis acid sites (L) on the surface. Additionally, other significant bands are observed, further elucidating the coordination dynamics. The band at 1636 cm⁻¹ suggests the presence of stronger Brønsted acid sites, characterized by a more intense interaction between pyridine and hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface, resulting in hydrogen bonding or the formation of protonated species. Meanwhile, the band at 1597 cm⁻¹ likely corresponds to Lewis acid site interactions, illustrating pyridine's coordination with metal sites. Importantly, the band at 1486 cm⁻¹ appears to be a composite signal arising from the overlap of pyridine interactions with both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, indicating a mixed acid site environment common among catalytic surfaces. This illustrates the complexity of the catalytic activities that may arise from such mixed sites [39,40,51]. The synthesized materials demonstrated surface properties and acidity that are ideally suited for use as heterogeneous catalysts. To assess their catalytic performance, we conducted experiments on the glycerol acetalization reaction with acetone, utilizing the prepared materials. The reaction was carried out under specific conditions established by Balotin et al. (2023), which included maintaining a temperature of 45 °C, employing a glycerol-to-acetone molar ratio of 1:4, and incorporating a catalyst load of 45.0 mg. This study aimed to explore the effectiveness of the synthesized materials in facilitating the reaction, thereby enhancing our understanding of their potential applications in catalytic processes. The results for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone using the catalysts (a) C-SiMo, (b) C-SiMoFe1, (c) C-SiMoFe2, and (d) C-SiMoFe3 are presented in Fig.9 (a–d). Fig. 9 illustrates the glycerol conversion across various tested catalysts. The main product of the reaction is solketal, while the 6MR (2,2-dimethyl-dioxolane-5-ol) is its byproduct. Notably, the C-SiMo catalyst, which contains 10 % molybdenum, achieved the percentage of glycerol conversion of 71.0 % and exhibited a strong selectivity for solketal, with minimal formation of 6MR. Conversely, the bifunctional catalysts incorporating iron and molybdenum demonstrated a positive correlation between iron content and the percentage of glycerol conversion. Specifically, the C-SiMoFe1 catalyst (0.5 % Fe and 10 % Mo) produced a glycerol conversion of 75.2 %, with enhanced selectivity for solketal relative to 6MR. The C-SiMoFe2 catalyst (1.5 % Fe and 10 % Mo) showcased the highest catalytic performance, achieving 83.5 % glycerol conversion, noted for its negligible 6MR production and an impressive solketal selectivity of 97.0 %. The C-SiMoFe3 catalyst, which incorporated a higher iron content, yielded 78.0 % glycerol conversion, while still maintaining a high selectivity for solketal. Fig. 10 presents the results of the acetalization reaction between glycerol and acetone over time. This study used the catalysts C-SiMo, C-SiMoFe1, C-SiMoFe2, and C-SiMoFe3. The curves in Fig. 10 show that all catalysts, except for C-SiMoFe1, exhibited rapid catalytic activity, reaching glycerol conversion values above 70.0 % within 120 min. Notably, the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst maintained superior performance, achieving conversions above 80.0 % under mild conditions, in line with the high conversion and selectivity for solketal observed in the previous study (Fig. 9). The increase in glycerol conversion observed across all catalysts highlights their role in facilitating the reaction by lowering the activation energy under isothermal conditions. C-SiMoFe1, despite achieving a slightly lower glycerol conversion of 75.2 % in the previous analysis, exhibited a more gradual reaction velocity, as shown in Fig. 9, indicating potential limitations in the availability or accessibility of active sites, which may affect the overall reaction kinetics. Based on the curves presented in Fig. 9, the specific initial reaction rates (r°glyc) expressed in mol of glycerol converted per minute per gram of catalyst, were calculated from the slope of the glycerol conversion versus time curve during the first 40 min of the reaction [26]. The catalyst C-SiMoFe2 exhibited the highest activity (3.95 × 10–3 mol·min⁻¹·g⁻¹cat), followed by C-SiMo (3.55 × 10–3mol·min⁻¹·g⁻¹cat), C-SiMoFe3 (3.30 × 10–3 mol·min⁻¹·g⁻¹cat), and C-SiMoFe1 (2.56 × 10–3 mol·min⁻¹·g⁻¹cat). The C-SiMoFe3 catalyst (2 % Fe) showed an intermediate r°glyc (3.30 × 10–3 mol·min⁻¹·g⁻¹cat), which may be due to the excess iron hindering access to the active sites. Among the catalysts evaluated, C-SiMoFe2 showed the best performance, suggesting a synergistic effect between molybdenum and the optimized iron content (1.5 %). The results obtained in terms of the conversion rate as a function of time reinforce the previous findings, highlighting the exceptional performance of the catalysts under mild reaction conditions. Achieving high conversion rates at room temperature offers significant advantages in terms of energy efficiency and operational simplicity, further confirming the potential of these materials. The impact of catalyst concentration on the yield of solketal was thoroughly assessed using the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst, with concentrations varying between 1.6 % and 5.0 % by weight. The data, illustrated in Fig. 11 (a), demonstrate a clear trend: as the catalyst concentration increases, the rate of solketal conversion rises correspondingly. According to the data shown in Fig. 11(a), at the 20-minute mark, the conversion increased progressively with the increase in catalyst loading. For reactions containing 1.6 %, 3.2 %, and 5 % catalyst by mass relative to glycerol, conversions of approximately 23 %, 38 %, and 50 % were observed, respectively. These results indicate that increasing the amount of catalyst enhances the availability of active sites, accelerates the reaction rate, and promotes higher conversion in a shorter period. After reaching a certain point, particularly around the 180-minute mark, a noticeable decline in conversion is observed. This decrease may stem from two primary factors: the reverse reaction of solketal formation and its hydrolysis, which could occur concurrently [52]. Based on these observations, the optimal conditions for catalytic conversion of solketal were determined to be a catalyst concentration of 5 % C-SiMoFe2 combined with a reaction time of 90 min. It is significant to note that throughout a prolonged reaction period of 250 min, there is a marked reduction in solketal concentration. This decline can be attributed to the hydrolysis process of solketal. To further evaluate the stability of the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst, a series of four successive reaction cycles was conducted. After each cycle, the catalyst was carefully recovered, washed with anhydrous ethanol, and dried at 120 °C for 24 h before being reused. The glycerol conversion values recorded for each cycle, as illustrated in Fig. 11(b), reveal an impressive initial conversion rate of 81 % in the first cycle. It is worth noting that the catalytic activity exhibited a gradual decline in subsequent cycles, with conversion values of 68 %, 69 %, and 48 % observed in the second, third, and fourth cycles, respectively. This behavior may be associated with slight leaching of the active metal species [53]. A proposed mechanism for the acetalization reaction of glycerol with acetone using the studied catalysts, involving activation of the carbonyl group by Brønsted acid sites generated by Mo species, is presented in Fig. 12 [8]. Iron species were not included in the proposed mechanism, as their main contribution was related to structural modifications of the catalyst. The reaction under discussion involves glycerol reacting with acetone through the activation of the carbonyl group. This activation can occur in two ways: either via protonation, which is facilitated by Brønsted acid sites, or through polarization due to coordination with Lewis acid sites associated with the metal cation. In this study, we propose that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites play significant roles in the reaction mechanism. FTIR analysis using pyridine confirmed that all molybdenum-modified catalysts tested exhibited both types of acid sites. However, it is important to note that Brønsted acid sites are the main contributors to high catalytic activity. This is supported by the poor catalytic performance observed in SiO₂ and SiO₂/Fe₂O₃-based materials, which do not have Brønsted acid sites, as previously studied for these materials. A similar observation was made in the studies conducted by Stawicka et al. (2016) [5]. The mechanism starts with the protonation of acetone's carbonyl group by the Brønsted acid sites of the catalyst. A lone pair from one of glycerol's hydroxyl groups then nucleophilically attacks this protonated carbonyl, forming an intermediate that undergoes dehydration to create a carbocation. This carbocation is attacked by glycerol's hydroxyl group through two pathways, forming two acetals: solketal (97 %) and 6MR (3 %). The predominance in the formation of the five-membered ring (solketal) over the six-membered ring is associated with steric repulsions arising from the presence of the methyl group in the axial position of the six-membered ring, which compromises its conformational stability [54,55]. Despite variations in the efficiency of the different catalysts regarding glycerol conversion, the selectivity toward solketal remained in the range of 97–98 %, as shown in Fig. 8, in agreement with the results reported by Ozorio et al. [55]. Table 2 compares the catalyst C-SiMoFe2 with other catalysts for the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, highlighting its efficiency and selectivity under mild conditions. C-SiMoFe2 achieved a percentage of glycerol conversion of 74 % and solketal selectivity of 97 % at a 1:4 glycerol/acetone molar ratio, 1.5 h, and 25 °C. These results are competitive with other low-cost, low-toxicity metal catalysts like Zr-S-400 and mesoporous niobiosilicate. C-SiMoFe's performance combines high selectivity with practical reaction conditions, indicating its potential for industrial applications and low environmental impact. 4 Conclusions The synthesized mesoporous catalysts demonstrated crucial structural characteristics, including the presence of active acid sites necessary for effective catalytic performance. The incorporation of iron facilitated better dispersion of molybdenum oxide, enhancing particle uniformity and improving the thermal stability of the molybdenum oxide component, as evidenced by thermogravimetric analysis. These catalysts exhibited superior activity in solketal synthesis, which can be attributed to the synergistic effect of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites alongside their mesoporous architecture. Notably, the C-SiMoFe2 catalyst achieved conversion rates exceeding 80 % at 25 °C. Additionally, the synthesis employed cost-effective raw materials and supports reactions under ambient conditions without solvents, positioning these catalysts as practical alternatives for industrial applications. The integration of high catalytic efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and sustainable practices underscores their potential as significant contributors to green chemistry initiatives. coredata.dc:description: This research aims to develop and characterize innovative metal-based catalysts made of micro-mesoporous silica enriched with iron and molybdenum. The goal is to optimize the acetalization of glycerol with acetone, promoting the production of the bioadditive solketal at ambient temperatures. X-ray diffraction analyses demonstrated the formation of orthorhombic molybdenum trioxide, showcasing excellent oxide dispersion on the support and remarkably low crystallinity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses have convincingly shown the presence of molybdenum (VI) and iron (III), signifying the successful formation of active species. By carefully optimizing conditions – specifically a reaction duration of 90 min, a temperature maintained at 25 °C, a catalyst loading of 5 % by weight (catalyst/glycerol), and a molar ratio of 1:4 (glycerol/acetone) – a conversion of 82 % and selectivity of 97 % for solketal were achieved. This result highlights the high efficiency and effectiveness of the proposed catalytic process. Reuse tests of the most efficient catalyst indicate satisfactory activity up to the third cycle, with a reduction in catalytic efficiency of 12 %, demonstrating high efficiency. These results demonstrate the great potential of these catalysts in sustainable industrial chemical processes, aligning with the innovative principles of green chemistry.
